column6: A housewarming goes sideways when Cody opens the wrong door—and stumbles into a world that shouldn't exist.
column9:
In the long, dragging years after college, all I could ever ask is to waste my life as efficiently as possible. 
It's like how I'm told falling in love is supposed to be: I can't pinpoint when the feeling began, only the realization that I was stuck in it, wading through a long, dark tunnel in the passageways of my mind, praying that the distant light approaching wasn't that of another train. Maybe it was the twenty-sixth hour awake at two o'clock in the library, on tha...

column6: A housewarming goes sideways when Cody opens the wrong door—and stumbles into a world that shouldn't exist.
column9:
Her face flushes in mere seconds. I struggle beneath her as she tensions the knife against my neck, and when I feel the edge scratch the stubble beneath my chin, the cold steel drawing the heat from my neck, I realize it's real enough to draw something else.
"You degenerate! You lecherous, filthy animal, breaking in my house to . . . to—"
She quickly retreats, her piercing, yellow eyes assessing me with stronger eye contact than I had at my first job interview.
I lack the mental capa...

column6: A housewarming goes sideways when Cody opens the wrong door—and stumbles into a world that shouldn't exist.
column9:
I wince at the pins and needles throbbing in my hand, thinking about how I'm gonna borrow my cousin and her law degree and sue that damn bitch. Engineering might make me just enough to get by beyond the mortgage, but there's no way in hell I'm paying for medical care. I'll take an Uber to the hospital before I call an ambulance.
Cursing under my breath makes it easier to bear. I tear the sleeve off my muddy, bloodstained shirt so I can try to wrap it up, all while I try to r...

column6: A housewarming goes sideways when Cody opens the wrong door—and stumbles into a world that shouldn't exist.
column9:
I wait until the four of them disappear into the shadows, then I try the handle of Katiya's door.
It's locked.
I run around the back, onto an unfamiliar cobblestone street, and counting as many houses over as it took to turn the corner, I try the window.
It's open.
I flex my left hand, still not feeling any anguish, pressing my ear to the window to try and discern where the girl is. I spend minutes listening to silence, until I hear my best friend's scream on the other side....

column6: Katiya tries to unwind, but duty—and an old flame—won't let her rest.
column9:
With every intention to relax, I try to let the peace of this place flood my tense muscles. But I wasn't made for this, and I hate drinking. The only thought on my inebriated mind are the words of my late father. And even if his last words were delivered as a whisper, they're far louder than the raucous trainees crowding Gaffe's End Tavern. 
He said that I would never find peace in shouldering the weight of all the world. He said it wasn't because I was weak, or that I was n...

column6: Katiya tries to unwind, but duty—and an old flame—won't let her rest.
column9:
It all starts when Chief Aldrin climbs the small stage. Tonight it's edicts instead of music, and he takes a swig from his mug to make sure the words sound like a toast instead of orders.
"It was three months ago that you all graduated in the top of your class. Instead of heading straight to the front lines, you were chosen to challenge yourself with a higher purpose. You demonstrated that you might have what it takes to join our ranks full-time. And starting tomorrow, you'll get your...

column6: Katiya tries to unwind, but duty—and an old flame—won't let her rest.
column9:
The fledgling Royal Knights form a line at the kegs, their mugs wavering as suds spill across the warped wooden floorboards. We raise our full cups as color drains from the sky, and somewhere across Lake Garrison, the faint amethyst glow of Chymaeran Essence emanates from the silhouetting pines.
I throw back another two fills on a challenge, and not long after, I find myself among the last of our group. Most of the others left to explore their new townhomes as official trainees of the Royal Gua...

column6: Another soul-numbing office day pushes Cody toward a choice he's not ready to make.
column9:
I realize I'm done working on the redline when my hands stop moving. Copying changes from a red-inked engineering drawing to the computer is easy enough to get lost in thought. The music from my brother's old IPod keeps the rhythm in the keys. I pop out one of the yellowed earbuds so the lyrics don't mince the words.
In the title block: DUNSMORE, 04/24/26.
Checked by SAKURASHIMA, 04/24/26. That means I have an excuse to let my crush Kei look at it.
Designed by PRADESH, the guy wh...

column6: Another soul-numbing office day pushes Cody toward a choice he's not ready to make.
column9: I retreat to my desk to doom-scroll through social media, trading the personal feeling of apathy for a more global feeling of hopelessness. It fills me with a certain kind of despair when I see all the marriage announcements of friends and acquaintances, like I've continuously been behind since I never dated in college: not even Kei. I had some fun, but I was too busy for anything meaningful. And as the only child left in my family, my parents beg for grandchildren like I used to beg for s...

column6: Another soul-numbing office day pushes Cody toward a choice he's not ready to make.
column9: A Bankers Box is the last thing I have to store away in the small closet beneath the stairs. It's somehow lived to service my family through many moves, and the yellowed white of the cardboard is long-aged to prove it.  First is the word OFFICE in my mother's cursive from twenty-some years ago. That was scratched out to say COLLEGE STUFF in my father's handwriting five years ago. Four years later, for the long move back, I amended that with a semicolon, adding ENGINEERING TEXTBOO...

column6: Nightmares, neighbors, and a base run: Katiya fights panic with routine until routine fights back.
column9:
The next lucid moment, I find myself pinned upside-down beneath a thick wooden rack. The heat climbs as I drag my heels across the floor, my clothes so black and charred that I pray my sweaty flesh might slick me back through the narrow space. Within the hot box of crackling logs and scalding cinders, the roar of recircling flames makes the house screech in agony when its bones crunch and crumble, casting twigs and thatch to the ashen floor.
The twisting and thrashing gets me nowhere, but when ...

column6: Nightmares, neighbors, and a base run: Katiya fights panic with routine until routine fights back.
column9:
It takes a couple seconds before my mind is able to catch up on two decades of living history. It's not the first time my mind tormented me with visions of another life, one where the Gods of fortune hadn't intervened. My episodes were worse in the Barracks: so bad that they threw me in with all the other traumatized children of the war that tossed and turned too much in their sleep, waking the others with the foreshadowing shouts and screams of the slaughter that might await them.
I ...

column6: Nightmares, neighbors, and a base run: Katiya fights panic with routine until routine fights back.
column9:
I descend the stairs in bare feet, carrying the thin cosmetic armor. The kitchen counters are vacant beyond some basic decorations: a bowl and a candle on every surface, what I've learned is the bare minimum for any military-issued living space. Part of me hopes for an explanatory note from Jullian, but I find nothing, just my bag of possessions scattered across the floor.
My stomach rumbles when my nose notices the commerce street is open. I spark the burners with Essence, throwing on som...

column6: Drinks with a best friend turn into confessions—and an idea Cody should ignore.
column9:
"Since you started on your first day, you haven't been drug tested. What's gonna change their mind on Monday, bro? My work never runs drug tests," he says. Gunfire cracks over the TV, flashing the empty walls with pops of color.
"No shit, Miguel. Their corporate structure banks on baked box-boys like you. The ones that forget they're lifting crates and stocking shelves and selling printers for eight hours a day."
"That's manager Miguel now — I order the little guys to ...

column6: Drinks with a best friend turn into confessions—and an idea Cody should ignore.
column9:
"No, I get what you're saying, but what do you mean?" Miguel says, slurring his words as he melts into the futon: the only piece of furniture our drunk asses could assemble. The overturned boxes are makeshift tables that keep the cans off the floor, since we're feeling too lazy to dig for a trash bag.
I lift the can to my lips, but I don't let the poison pass the threshold. Past experience tells me that I'm toeing my limit: lost enough to let my stupid emotions leak on my fa...

column6: A distant light rattles Gaffesend; Katiya's first day ends with an intruder at home.
column9:
"So we're already finished. Is that as bad as it gets? Or is this just because it's the first day?" Pax asks. "Maybe Aldrin wasn't lying. I thought we'd be at the enemy's doorstep most days, waiting for one of them to break through." He chows down on a raw potato that he withdraws from his pocket, spitting scraps with every syllable. "But this is great — a little work for as much produce as you can eat!"
"As long as you don't get caught, you idiot," Ryder say...

column6: A distant light rattles Gaffesend; Katiya's first day ends with an intruder at home.
column9:
I pass the threshold of the gate, gasping for breaths as my last sprint dissolves into a jog. It becomes immediately obvious that weren't the only ones to notice: most of the recruits gather outside the guard post, swarming around the re-purposed adventurers' guild like flies to excrement. 
I spot my brother Erik leaning against the doorframe.
"What's happening?" I ask.
"Some major Essence event."
"Yeah, we saw it. We were on the southern hills." 
I gasp for breath. He hands me h...

column6: A distant light rattles Gaffesend; Katiya's first day ends with an intruder at home.
column9:
"What was that about?" Bertram asks. The grasp of his hands on my torso is so strong that I hardly have to walk.
"I ... I don't know," I tell him. "I thought I got over this. I thought I wasn't so damn weak and pathetic..."
"You're not pathetic! You earned your presence here," he assures me. "You had a bad day, is all."
"But how can I last when it's really down to the wire, when it's real, if my mind fights me at something so simple, so stupid and pathetic and weak, lik...

column6: Through Katiya's eyes: a door, a modern nightmare, and a blur she can't unsee. and violence.
column9:
If he wasn't handsome, I would have slit his throat. My mind can't catch up fast enough for all the semantics, but I know exactly what he means.
I can feel it.
My face flushes. "You degenerate! You lecherous, filthy animal, breaking into my house to . . . to—"
"I swear, I didn't break in here," he insists. His face is redder than mine. He covers his crotch with his hands, as if hiding the pitched tent can make me forget. "The door was open. I just walked in."
"The door was ...

column6: Through Katiya's eyes: a door, a modern nightmare, and a blur she can't unsee. and violence.
column9:
I rush to the window, throwing the shades open just enough to peer into the darkness, drawn by my biting curiosity to see what unfolds.  What an idiot — now he's struggling to tear the sleeve off his bloodstained shirt, ripping at the fabric where my Essenced plume singed it black.
But it still bothers me. Why was he so drawn to the shallow closet? Even under duress, I don't know how he could be stupid enough to insist he entered through a door. There's surely nothing in th...

column6: Misread motives turn their encounter into a full-on clash.
column9:
I wager my strength and power over his defenses. The inebriated man called Cody holds the odd, metallic broomstick with his hands together in the center — a technique I've never seen before — and calls out a phrase I can only decipher as a challenge.
If it's a sword fight he wants, I know I can make it to the greatsword leaning against the wall, because if this Auvryan cross-blood wants to wreak havoc on my home life with his illusions, sullying the most sacred place I hav...

column6: Misread motives turn their encounter into a full-on clash.
column9:
Whatever that thing is, it isn't a broom.
My mind races, but I still manage to remember the bloody dagger in the sink.
I roll behind the kitchen island as he brandishes the head of the stick against a wooden bowl on the counter, casting a whole slew of produce against the ground.
I lift myself by the counter's edge to dig my hand into the sink, feeling for the hilt of the dagger. 
"Your fight is with me, not the damn house!" I say.
He bends down to scoop up one of the apples with the ...

column6: Cody barricades more than a door as reality refuses to make sense.
column9:
Late Sunday morning, around 11:00, I awoke with my neck twisted against the closet door, my face saturated with drool, shirt missing, and a sticky note taped to my forehead with Miguel's handwriting that read "DRINK WATER." The pounding headache had mostly subsided: I must have slept it off, or drank loads of water the night before from how quickly I immediately had to sprint to the restroom. And after relieving myself, I found my phone on the counter with three unread texts:
<span class=m...

column6: Cody barricades more than a door as reality refuses to make sense.
column9:
"Nice to meet you all. I'm Reed Broderick," he says. The executive hands him two dozen donuts, and he puts them on the table. "I've heard this is how you make an impression." 
"You heard right," Kei says. The animals all reach their hands for the box, but I lean further against the wall. 
"So where are you from, Reed?" Michael asks, his mouth full of donut. "And how old are you? We've got a lot of young ones on this team now." 
"Twenty-eight. I graduated last year with a Mechanic...

column6: A month later, a public moment goes wrong—and Katiya can't shake the blame.
column9:
I take deep breaths as I try not to let him break me. Cody's gone now. And I will never have to deal with him again.
I dig my heels into the space between the floorboards, catching my breath as I drive my back against the closet door. My nails tension against the pad of my palm, leaving crescents in my flesh as the blood drains from my fingertips. 
My heart can only take so much in a day. I thought the enemy could only strike when my presence was voluntary; when I patrol the borders of Gaf...

column6: A month later, a public moment goes wrong—and Katiya can't shake the blame.
column9:
ONE MONTH LATER

...

column6: A month later, a public moment goes wrong—and Katiya can't shake the blame.
column9: There's no early breaks in all the domestic quests. It only took a couple days before I realized that sitting on the job was a bad image, unless you have a lunch pail in your hands. Just like any routine — whether it's a new cycle of combat training, classes, or a new job — the first three days are memorable because it's all so fresh. I thought taking different quests would make each day distinct from the last, but from the fourth day onward, it all became a blur of m...

column6: A month later, a public moment goes wrong—and Katiya can't shake the blame.
column9: They're close enough to run me over, but my body's trained to react before I can think. Muscle memory comes before thought, thought before fear, and fear before true reaction, so it's only when I'm halfway across the road that the thoughts finally reach my muscles. The others are only beginning to notice when the Chymaeran fleshwalker raises the rifle. I'm the only one that happened to know enough and be close enough to respond, and when I try to take another step, I fe...

column6: Praise falls on the wrong desk. At home, Cody hears a voice on the other side.
column9:
I can only work as fast as the computer will take me, choosing to try and save the file every chance I get. I've spent so many hours imagining how I would boost the performance if IT gave me a blank check, and I was the bottleneck. Although a workstation laptop is nice to take home, it has nothing over one of those stationary rigs that the Robinson-Monroe lifers were grandfathered into.
They gave me the laptop two years ago, and it hasn't been updated since. One day I booted into BIOS...

column6: Praise falls on the wrong desk. At home, Cody hears a voice on the other side.
column9:
"Hey bro. I was thinking we could talk about the project later," he says.
What is this, an undergrad lab? Is there a grade?
"Yeah, that'd be cool," I say.
"What's your phone number? I already got Kei's last week. I was thinking we could make a group chat," he says.
"Uh, yeah, man, sure." I take his phone. I enter CODY WORK in the top, and the ten digits in the box. He shoots me a text of the first three emojis in his "recent" bar, and then proceeds to make the group message right...

column6: Praise falls on the wrong desk. At home, Cody hears a voice on the other side.
column9:
I toss my keys on the counter: the house is a moderate mess when my parents aren't coming the day after. I slip my hand down my pants and grab the TV remote (not for porn), fixing the sweaty adhesion I'd dealt with since the afternoon.
Reed messages about the happy hour in the involuntary group chat. He reminds me of my brother. And, surprisingly, Kei says she's going, too.
They ask me if I'm coming, but the darkness of the foyer is too comfortable. All I want is to do nothi...

column6: With help scarce, Katiya runs toward the only lifeline left.
column9: Calling his name will do nothing. I decide ahead of time to break in instead of patiently knocking, hoping the others piece together my purpose for panic instead of thinking I'm just deserting. My two friends are built like bricks, but it's all the muscle that helps in a sprint. If Bertram's house were any further than three blocks, they might have fallen behind. My legs are long and my conditioning is great, but it's not enough. I feel one of them lift me into the air as I ...

column6: With help scarce, Katiya runs toward the only lifeline left.
column9:
When we arrive, the spaces between the buildings are strangely vacant. The escaped horses are hitched back to the familiar carriage, parked at the side of the headquarters: surely the royals are elsewhere, enjoying the finest accommodations.  I can hear a loud group of guards and civilians within the walls. I lament the straight walk through the center of the building we'll have to take to get Bertram the attention he needs.
I can hear the voices of the commoners.
"If your guards were smar...

column6: A midnight crossing. A stranger's kindness. Rules they'll both pretend to follow.
column9:
Words are a currency she can't afford when her panic sets her over the edge. She speaks in strings of syllables I can't comprehend, but it's not her desperate cries that confuse me the most.
It's the fact that the last four weeks passed so peacefully. I thought this was all just a dream after that drunken night with Miguel, but the beautiful girl I mistook for a cosplayer chokes on her tears between breaths as she buries her face into my arm.
"They've all abandoned me,"...

column6: A midnight crossing. A stranger's kindness. Rules they'll both pretend to follow.
column9:
I wake again from dreams of fire. My hand is always first to feel for the other side of the bed, but my fingers are already laced in something.
I long so deeply for something warm to hold. I want the heat to quell my panic, to overwrite the memories and feelings that sensation brings with something warm that's better. The cabin is collapsing again: no windows or doors, just a hot box of logs crumbling under the weight of my father's weakness, and I can feel my own muscles tension furt...

column6: "Welcome to the future." A car ride and a big-box errand become an emotional obstacle course.
column9:
I never knew it was possible to misunderstand a taco. It seems pretty obvious that it's tall and narrow. That you have to rotate the thing sideways to put it in your mouth to take a bite, but Katiya wedged her teeth between the middle of the shell, taking bites like a chipmunk as she complained that the shell might spill it all.
Nor did I ever consider how the taste of processed food might be too much for someone that eats an antiquated diet of fruit and bread and meat, taken aback by how ...

column6: "Welcome to the future." A car ride and a big-box errand become an emotional obstacle course.
column9:
He spends a near ten minutes trying to find twenty different ways to demand that I sit in the exact same place without touching anything. That I'm safe. That I can't possibly get hurt, regardless of how fast we go. That anything foreign and strange and big and too impossibly smooth is there for a reason, and that nothing is going wrong unless he says it is, and that he'll surely bring it up if things are even slightly bad.
He doesn't press the glowing switch on the wall for ...

column6: "Welcome to the future." A car ride and a big-box errand become an emotional obstacle course.
column9:
"Just try not to make too much eye contact with anyone," Cody says. "They already think you do dress-up from the color your eyes are."
"But how could they? Are there any other races here?"
"Just humans," Cody says. "So boring and dissimilar we call different skin colors different races, can you believe that?"
"No," I tell him, pushing the cart by its wheels instead of lifting it by the side.
The store is so flooded with people that it reminds me of my late childhood in the capital. But it seems...

column6: Cody tours Katiya's world—and fits in a little too well.
column9:
"Have you tried an Eglich?" She asks.
"No. Running is for people that hate themselves."
"I guess it fits, then," she says: lacing up a set of minimalist running sandals that look like what the weirdos from Cross Country used to wear. "You sprint for a while, then jog. And you do it again and again until you make it back."
"Or you don't. And you're sure this is safe?"
"Running?"
"No. Being out there," I mean.
"I was out in your world, wasn't I? It's no different for you. Same...

column6: Cody tours Katiya's world—and fits in a little too well.
column9:
He never overtakes me, now that I feel so efficient. Without the weight of my chest digging deeper trenches in the flesh of my shoulders, I feel so much lighter: my mind freed enough to take in the sights instead of staving off the thought of suffering.
It's morning just like it is in Cody's world, but the air feels fresher: not saturated with the smell of gas and engines like the capital. Sometimes I wonder if Cody's world traded the splendor of nature for every other sensation ...

column6: Cody tours Katiya's world—and fits in a little too well.
column9:
"You're the science fella," Paxton says, taking a deep swig from the mug in our favorite spot in front of the window. "So you're here for a while, huh?
"The Royal Academy sent me here for a while," Cody lies, reciting the story we rehearsed on the tail end of the run. He crushes the ale almost as fast as Ryder and Pax do, because he was in some alcohol training program in college — at least from how he explained it to me.
I managed to gather all of us at the front of the bar: Al...

column6: A lunch with Dad. A memory of a brother. A door that might be open tonight.
column9:
"I think that will work just fine," Reed says. "What do you think?"
But he's not talking to me. He's approached almost every engineer in the office to ask their opinion about his design choices, and now he's back there with Wilbur, preventing him from dozing back off into his "wake apnea".
I scratch away at the yellow engineering pad, sketching my own ideas instead of relying on others all the damn time. It's easy to draw in 3D when it's just a plate with a few holes in...

column6: A lunch with Dad. A memory of a brother. A door that might be open tonight.
column9:
We're snaking down the switchbacks of Shaleborough Canyon when he decides to take another dig at me.
"I don't think I've ever seen your car this clean." He drags one of his dirty fingers across the dashboard.
"It'll only get dirtier if you get your greasy paws all over it," I tell him.
"Did a girl finally make it into your life? Sweet Jesus, I thought you'd be stuck in that game room of yours playing the Nintendo forever," he says.
"Maybe I did," I say. "Or maybe some g...

column6: A lunch with Dad. A memory of a brother. A door that might be open tonight.
column9: The rest of the day passes slowly when everybody else is gone: everybody besides Kei and I. The lifers leave early: forced to come in when it's still dark out so they can take care of their teenagers — or if they don't have kids, maybe drink at the bar or something. The young type-A engineers leave a little after so they can make the most of summer's long evenings, whether it's running or biking  out on the trails in the open fields between the housing developments, or...

column6: Katiya chases a thief and a ghost from her past—while promises tug her toward tomorrow.
column9:
I refuse to let in a chance for anything to happen, and that's why I rise early. Earlier than the knocker that comes to wake me. Earlier than the sun: early enough that the morning hours mask my presence while I wear the hood of my uniform, tucking my golden locks of braided hair beneath the fabric.
There's still the early risers that do their training in the mornings, and with the approach of our first competencies that all city guards are required to take, the training fields and t...

column6: Katiya chases a thief and a ghost from her past—while promises tug her toward tomorrow.
column9:
"I want to apologize to you," Jullian says.
He takes my hand as we swelter inside the guard tent. I thought an open-air bazaar meant a cooling breeze might flow through every once in a while—or that the tattered tarp above our heads might block the rays—but the air scalds our lungs like sitting in a kiln.
He parts his chapped lips, and his eyes trace the floor in the same tick of nervousness he's had since I met him. But there are still signs we've grown together. And when...

column6: Katiya chases a thief and a ghost from her past—while promises tug her toward tomorrow.
column9:
I'm lucky my panic catches when I'm two stories off the ground: gravity doesn't hinder my hesitation, but only aids it. The panic makes me hold fast to the metal contact: siphoning the friction of the Essence into my circuits in a rejuvenating reversal.
The energy cycles through my body from my arms to my legs, and though my blood freezes with the initial surge of panic, my circuits are scalding with power. The vibrations in the tether rattle the bones in my arms, casting sparks ...

column6: Katiya chases a thief and a ghost from her past—while promises tug her toward tomorrow.
column9:
"That wasn't our job! That was stupid and senseless," Jullian says. He looks at the bare flesh of my arm, scratched enough from rolling on roof stones that it bleeds in a staccato of open cuts. 
I can feel his power mend my flesh as we walk back across the abandoned fields, warming the skin and coaxing it to join again.
"I thought you'd react differently," I say, cradling the artifact in my good arm.
"I think that was reckless, and you could have gotten yourself killed." He looks at t...

column6: A training mishap puts Cody on someone important's radar for all the wrong reasons.
column9: It came scrawled in messy letters that weren't from my world, written on a piece of vellum fresh with ink. It was only four words that would send a chill down any man's spine: especially if they came smaller on the screen of a smartphone. Cody: We need to talk. - Katiya But it came with a plate that wasn't from my world, like some kind of antique I'd find at my g...

column6: A training mishap puts Cody on someone important's radar for all the wrong reasons.
column9:
"If you're on the line right now, you don't mind the chance of getting hurt," Aldrin says. His eyes scan the thirsty townies standing behind the line of rope. "Just because you don't get to drink first if you don't do the course does NOT mean you won't drink at all."
"But all the fucking ale will be gone!" One of the beer-gutted strongmen says. Even the hesitant men now join the line, shouting in agreement.
"Well, it's not a race: it's a course," Aldrin says....

column6: Open house at work: new faces, old history, and a wall Cody isn't on.
column9:
And so I sell him a lie.
"I just don't see how this shirt looks any different," I say, "you know?"
He glares at me through the door. "Different? You still look like you were ripped out of the high Middle Ages." 
I have no idea what he means. "But it's a shirt with a collar, right?" I ask. "I don't have the fancy noble clothes from your world. This was woven by hand!"
"And it looks like you're off to add your name to the Drclaration Of Independence," he says. Cody cracks a sm...

column6: Open house at work: new faces, old history, and a wall Cody isn't on.
column9:
The installation looks like one of those dug-in shelters on the border of the Purgatory Line, and when we enter the quaint area dug into the side of the mountain, facing the set of reflective steel doors, I expect they'll open to a grand chamber beneath the ground.
But when Cody's paramour presses the glowing arrow button, the doors slide open with a chime, exposing a tiny room that the three of us enter. The metal doors are just about to close when a fourth guy shows up, sticking his...

column6: Open house at work: new faces, old history, and a wall Cody isn't on.
column9:
I spend the rest of the day in Cody's shadow, avoiding long conversations with his coworkers and eating as much of the free food as we can. And after watching as many of the children's science demonstrations as possible — while Cody eagerly riffed on about all these concepts named after scientists — we take a break on the east balcony that opposes the view from the elevator, looking out across his world's well-developed landscape.
"But it's fluids," I say. "You s...

column6: Double dates, mixed signals, and the uneasy question: are we still who we were?
column9:
She waits until I'm fully seated in the car to tell me the news. And when she does, I feel both relieved and horrified at the same time — like the wife that tells her husband he's packing the largest out of all his friends.
"You did what?" I ask. "Really? But when?"
"It's when you were busy moping around behind the ration trucks," Katiya says, with a smug grin. "But I didn't embarrass you too much."
I start the car, mute the volume, then feel my head lower into my hand...

column6: Double dates, mixed signals, and the uneasy question: are we still who we were?
column9: Kei laughs, crossing her legs as she sits across from me in the train car. "So you didn't realize that this is exactly the same date we went on all those years ago?" So it is a date, I think, rubbing the stubble on my chin that I shaved for the first time in months. "I guess not," I say. "I mean, the last one with you was probably the last real date I've been on." "Real one, huh?" She leans in closer, showing that same mischievous grin that com...

column6: Double dates, mixed signals, and the uneasy question: are we still who we were?
column9:
And so I press my lips against his to try to forget.
The feeling has hunted me since we left Gaffesend in the carriage. It seems to trail every time that Jullian and I get together. It builds with the crescendo of all the unspoken questions: the useless questions that get us nowhere; the useless, pathetic questions that drive a larger wedge between us, preventing us from just enjoying things the way they are.
What more can I want?
The driver of this personal carriage is distracted by the noise ...

column6: Double dates, mixed signals, and the uneasy question: are we still who we were?
column9:
"I'm glad we could do this together," Kei says. "After all these years."
And I realize our entire date has passed in a blur.
We sit downtown at some sushi restaurant on 16th Street Mall. I said all the funny things at all the right times. I made sure to drink as much as I could when we went bowling, to loosen up a little, because even if alcohol makes me feel the call of the void the day after, I need to steal that emotional currency from my future self.
Fact is that we walked into most of...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
I grit my teeth and continue to descend into the cold tub. My body aches, but not yet from the freezing water. It's from the pain of how heavy-handed those backwater Ahkvasans are — digging their manicured claws into the thinnest muscles on our backs, extracting pain from our overworked muscles by dealing it. And now I'm tasked to withstand the freezing water for a couple minutes, because it's supposedly good for me.
"No Essence," Jullian says, seemingly humored by my suffe...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
I have just enough strength to lead us: after all, I'm the only one whose liver was trained for endurance in the fraternity house.
It feels like I have a knot in my stomach, wondering if all those sushi rolls expanded from the liquor — like the time Jackson swallowed those "Just Add Water" dinosaur toy pills from the dollar store. The doctor pulled them out of his throat like a rope of colorful ribbons from the mouth of a clown. But I feel like mine will be able to come out all on th...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
"I just want to go home," I tell Jullian, as soon as I exit the locker room.
"But we have a whole night here," he says. "I'm not sure I can get a refund."
But I'm already headed for the front of the complex, carrying my towel and overnight bag.
"Katiya, wait!" He says.
"And where was all that enthusiasm earlier?" My hand tensions further around the straps of the bag as I turn to face him, something he's obviously incapable of. "If you're so damn interested in changing the pr...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
Something in me twists at that word. 
Something that I haven't felt for a long time, and after all the events of the evening, I'm losing control of that edge.
Surely it's the booze from the way the tears leak from my eyes a little, but the train car back is dark, and when I press my nose to the scratched window glass, feeling the vibrations of the rails, I feel that feeling steady itself just a little more.
But the more it settles, the more distance I feel between the two of us, ...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
And maybe that peace was never there. Maybe he was always longing for something and just used me as a rope to climb out.
"We were both losers when we met," I say. "We lifted each other up!"
"But I was able to get over my fears. You still cower in them every day," Jullian says. "Not going on a single patrol quest? Have you even looked at the status board lately? Have you trained combat in any drop-ins? Have you even been inside the base?"
"No, I haven't," I say. "But did you think you had i...

column6: Cold water and hard truths—two relationships strain to the breaking point.
column9:
I refuse to close my eyes or else I might fall asleep. 
I blare music on the shared work playlist we made together, skipping all the classical and post-rock shit and going straight for the bangers.
It's funny how I always dreamed of her sitting in this car next to me, right in the passenger seat. Last time, we were both in the back. It was right after my parents bought me this used car for my birthday, because it had all the right "safety features" in some parenting magazine, and it was ho...

column6: Tests expose strengths, flaws, and a calm rival who never seems to miss.
column9:
Inspired. Soulful. And as unpredictable as possible. 
It was the way my instructors in the Northaven military academy told me to approach my combat: that there were only so many techniques they could teach us to commit to memory, that the artistry of the process would have to supersede the mechanics.
But I was far from inspired or soulful when I woke up three hours ago: the first time in a while that the rapping of the knocker beat me to breakfast, causing me to rush through the motions of gett...

column6: Tests expose strengths, flaws, and a calm rival who never seems to miss.
column9:
"I hear we're presenting to Kei and the rest of the team," Reed says, sipping on his second cup of coffee. He drinks that shit to calm down, while I chug energy drinks just to stay awake.
He invited me to walk around the building. Usually I turn him down, but this time, he said he wanted to talk about our presentations — and unthreatened by his grandiose design I peeked at every time I passed his computer, I decided to oblige. 
We walk shoulder-to-shoulder around the rectangular buil...

column6: Tests expose strengths, flaws, and a calm rival who never seems to miss.
column9:
I'm certain that today is when it all finally reaches me. It's not because of the spread of punched holes in the target, nor is it the gossip and glare of cadets that watch us atop the old castle walls.
It's the unpracticed way the weight of the armor restrains my body. For so long, the cosmetic shell of thin steel was all I wore on my missions in the interior. Swinging my arms down with a wooden sword feels foreign when my hands have calloused more from benign fieldwork. All my ...

column6: A tough room for Cody. A tougher match for Katiya. Plans buckle under pressure.
column9:
My presentation begins after the seven of them settle into the semicircle of office chairs, searching for the words to begin as my body blocks the blinding glow of the projector's rays.
The room is dimly lit, and so their seven silhouettes are hard to distinguish when the projector's lens burns the first slide into my retinas, reading CODY DUNSMORE, BATTERY SOLUTION across the Navidson-Monroe PowerPoint template. 
The sixteen-point Arial text is just the right size in the center of th...

column6: A tough room for Cody. A tougher match for Katiya. Plans buckle under pressure.
column9:
Only the Gods above know how the other team will answer my plan. Beads of sweat absorb in the weave of the golden headband, without the exertion to warrant it: we've been advancing so slowly this whole time. But the light piece of fabric feels heavier than any piece of armor I'm wearing.
The old servants' quarter is so silent I can hear the cadets' conversations atop the walls. And though the voice inside my head is louder, recalling every moment I could have prepared for th...

column6: One wins the crowd; the other loses control. Lines are drawn on both sides.
column9:
Reed's entirely prepared as he advances towards his last slide. In the lower corner, it reads 20 OF 20: even with a custom progress bar to show the stages of his presentation.
"And, again, here's a full view of my assembly," he says. "Not animated in that cool way like Cody's, but I've colored each of the parts." Each of the five parts: two more than the current design already uses. And although his design looks really cool—with even the company logo laser-etched into ...

column6: One wins the crowd; the other loses control. Lines are drawn on both sides.
column9:
If I don't act now, I won't have a home to return to. When my shoulder bludgeons open the door to the roofless, charred edifice, it is not an act of courage, but the response of a frightened girl that can't resist the currents of fear.
I flow like water from the heights of terror to the lowest point of controlled panic: just an autonomous reaction, and I rue the fact that I haven't the mental space for clever and quickness. My trembling hand grasps the chalked wooden dagger ...

column6: Back at the house, two people who need comfort get conflict instead.
column9:
Sometimes this numbness can be a blessing in the same way that it's a curse. 
It's a curse that makes tearful graduation speeches from my father sound like lectures from a professor. It makes moments of intimacy with the woman I thought I I'd end up with feel like a meaningless hookup. But in moments of toleration — whether it's the long, dragging pledge process, an hour-and-a-half waiting for a new license at the DMV, or the verbal lashing I received from Naveen &mdas...

column6: Back at the house, two people who need comfort get conflict instead.
column9:
Cody pulls in the garage a little after 17:30. I hope it's excitement that brought him home so quickly: maybe to relay the news, that the presentation gave him everything he ever wanted. I was happy to be a spectator for his rehearsal this morning, though I wasn't listening to a word of it. It wasn't because I didn't care. It was less because I didn't understand, and more from rising panic over the demands of my competency test.
I couldn't stand to stand or sit or ...

column6: Years earlier, in a storm of ice and static, a mission hangs by a thread.
column9:
It's the cold snap that brings him back again.
The cold snap of steel-on-steel on the press-check as he sits in the starboard door seat of the helicopter, just fiddling with it at this point, having recited the words and pictures of the plan a hundred times over.
The six-man patrol of an Army long-range surveillance detachment flies under the cover of darkness in the predawn hours, kept awake by the thrum of the rotor — and the talk of anything that might distract them. First it was ...

column6: Years earlier, in a storm of ice and static, a mission hangs by a thread.
column9:
The sun foreshadows dawn with a hint of deep red, but the cloud cover still saturates the sky, offering an extra hour of absolute darkness, and in that time, a long thirty minutes pass until they arrive.
They pick a fold of the landscape that gives eyes to the valley, but still masked by the shadows of the western slope. Helten runs micro-recon on wind direction and snow density, muttering coordinates in MGRS as Dunsmore transcribes them into the tablet. Gjersee and Aberbook unroll the camo cov...

column6: Years earlier, in a storm of ice and static, a mission hangs by a thread.
column9:
"This is all my fault," Dunsmore mutters. His voice trembles: their LRF detachment wasn't intended for combat, and six M4 rifles against the concentrated might of the enemy feels like lobbing stones at an M1 Abrams tank.
"You can't control the weather," Gjersee mutters, just as the shrill sound of snowmobile engines undercuts the whine of the alarm. But Dunsmore eyes the antenna, allowing shame to stir his emotions towards an act of courage. 
Helten urges them to move. Keller keeps tr...

column6: Long before today, a childhood dare turned into a scar that never closed.
column9:
"Why is it so hard for you to let go?" The question comes from thirty feet below. 
Three young boys stare up at the dense canopy of trees, squinting their eyes to watch as the girl makes her way across the branch, approaching the point where two trees are ten seasons from shaking hands. 
"How did you even get up there?" A boy asks, watching from the ground as she dangles above the village's ancient stone wall.
"The bark of these trees thicken with age," the girl says, swaying with the long...

column6: Long before today, a childhood dare turned into a scar that never closed.
column9:
At twenty-eight, Katiya and Bertram are already halfway across the field, stumbling over uneven patches of dirt as they run as fast as their bodies will let them. Raph and Raven are laughing gaily as they cross the threshold of the tree line at eighteen, followed by Katiya at fifteen, and Bertram at fourteen — choking on the rancid taste of exhaustion in his breath as he struggles to keep up.
Nhytyx's voice gets louder after they break the edge of the field, and it sounds ever-presen...

column6: Long before today, a childhood dare turned into a scar that never closed.
column9:
It's the cold snap that brings her back again, to find herself floating in a pit of flesh and brine. She must have been warmed by the panic of her rapid breathing in the last moment she remembers: feeling her meager volume of Essence sear her skin with the powers of fire she hadn't even learned yet.
And in the odd moment of stillness, before she finds the space for the newfound habit of panic to arrest her again, she wonders if she's made it to the Reservoir of Souls when she loo...

column6: Small progress, big disappointment—until a late-night spark hints at a dangerous idea.
column9:
"I want you to know that you've improved a lot since the incident last quarter," Nav says. He scrolls through notes on the tablet's touchscreen as he sits across from me in the dinky, makeshift break room — the break room he booked as a conference room for our weekly one-on-one.
I don't say anything. I just nod until it gets him to continue, speaking further about deadlines and redlines and upcoming builds that he'll just regurgitate in our standup meeting, trying to f...

column6: Small progress, big disappointment—until a late-night spark hints at a dangerous idea.
column9:
I thought approaching the table to congratulate my rival would be the last I'd have to see him today. I left before he got the new insignia for his cubicle's nametag, before all the other strangers could approach him and offer their praise.
But when I saw the large, crumpled box labeled MCMASTER-CARR on his desk, taped with a manifest from the machinists' cell with REWORK emblazoned in a large red stamp, I should have known he'd suffer quietly for another thirty minutes afte...

column6: Small progress, big disappointment—until a late-night spark hints at a dangerous idea.
column9:
My steel-toed shoes crunch the dry leaves beneath my feet as I descend the crumbling stairs, eyes watering from the hills of dry grass in late fall, and even though the failures of the day turn over in my mind for the full ride home, I still find the energy to toil a while longer in the garage — working on soldering for some stupid project that's captured my free time when I'm still not friends with any of my neighbors.
And in the silence of the dark garage, I'm lit only by...

column6: Family news brightens the table, but Katiya's hands won't stop shaking. A walk with Erik ends at a tavern door—and a choice she should've made months ago.
column9:
"Stop. Please," I beg them, rolling my eyes as I sit across the table. The tremor in my hand's been going for about a month now, so I rest my wrist on table between bites of stew, or else the metal spoon will shake in my grasp.
"Stop telling my daughter that I'm proud of her?" Stella asks. "Of my two children risking their lives to defend the empire?"
"I'm defending nothing right now," I remind her, gesturing to my brother. "It's him that's doing all the work."
Erik tak...

column6: Family news brightens the table, but Katiya's hands won't stop shaking. A walk with Erik ends at a tavern door—and a choice she should've made months ago.
column9:
I leave dinner, but the feeling overstays. It's rare for my brother and I to walk the same way since we live in two different parts of town: I live in the west half with all the apprentices, while Erik has settled into the employed half. But it still takes a long walk north to get to our split.
These walks are the only time I've been able to see him, and I still struggle to reconcile how much he's changed since he left for Gaffesend while I was still training in the academy in No...

column6: Family news brightens the table, but Katiya's hands won't stop shaking. A walk with Erik ends at a tavern door—and a choice she should've made months ago.
column9:
I feel that hesitation strike in fear of all I have to lose, almost giving me pause. But I find its blows are far too weak. Maybe I've hesitated twice before to save Bertram, but now, I don't hesitate to save myself.
I put my hand on his shoulder, resisting the urge to knock his block off.
He turns around.
"Oh, Katiya?" He says. "I thought . . . thought that we were on a . . ."
"I should have never waited for this to happen," I say. "Ever since we got here, and I saw you change so rap...

column6: Family news brightens the table, but Katiya's hands won't stop shaking. A walk with Erik ends at a tavern door—and a choice she should've made months ago.
column9:
I decided I'd run it tonight after everyone left. It was just to see what it could change when I've been snagged on the same design for months. Even though I should have accepted that I had enough for an entry-level project, the raw feeling of anger coupled with a longing for retribution, and I wanted to feel better at any cost.
At five-thirty, the floor was dark. I went out there with only the emergency lights on, missing security and custodial staff that might have asked me to turn ...

column6: New alliances form while an ominous email threatens Cody's career.
column9:
They say to never challenge an Ahkvasan to a foot race: you might be faster, but you still won't get there in time. 
I must be fortunate that she decided for us to walk instead of run, because even if she has half the blood of the Ahkva, I can feel time slow ever so slightly 
when I'm near her—and not as a figure of speech. Maybe she slows the world around us because she needs more time to unscrew all the bottled thoughts she has: the gentle ones; the ones she couldn't spil...

column6: New alliances form while an ominous email threatens Cody's career.
column9:
"How the hell do you manage to do it?" I ask Reed, fighting the urge to yawn as I finish my last set on bench press. My arms tremble as he lifts lightly, forcing a useful kind of suffering until I make it to the top.
"I don't know," he says. "I think I've played this game since my father bought me my first zip-on tie, for catholic confirmation. And then it was middle school student council. Then high school president. Then business clubs in college, and it just kind of happened, becau...

column6: New alliances form while an ominous email threatens Cody's career.
column9:
"I was the stabilizer of my family," Aryn says. "My veins and circuits run cold. I don't have access to that thing you have."
We're both facing the lake, watching the sun peek over the Purgatory Mountains to shimmer a line in the choppy water.
"This thing is eroding me," I tell her, and I can even feel it now as we turn our backs to the spaces between the slender trees. 
"But you're alive," Aryn says. "Thought and reason make soldiers, but soul and spirit make warriors."
"Or cowa...

column6: New alliances form while an ominous email threatens Cody's career.
column9:
And when I see the boundless energy he has that attracts allies like moths to flame, I feel my own sense of envy in my rival's strength. I even think of Katiya a little: that fiery look of ambition when she's debating a point, or fighting me off with a sword, and part of me misses her — I think she's the last girl I talked to besides my mother, and it was a damn argument.
My phone vibrates in my pocket, and when Reed is deep in our last set of Russian twists with a medicine...

column6: A collapse, a break-in, and a rescue drag Katiya and Cody violently back together.
column9:
It was a walk so it doesn't count. And it doesn't matter if I've worked a long day questing.
The static returns to my hands when I sit idle on my sofa. Listening to the sounds on the electric music box named JACKSON'S IPOD only worked for so long until it ran out of power, unchargeable by Essence from my hands—and though the hear-buds' end fits into the phone Cody got me, I don't have many sounds I've saved to play.
But he made me a playing list on an ap...

column6: A collapse, a break-in, and a rescue drag Katiya and Cody violently back together.
column9:
I just want to go home, but now more than ever. I rushed through every redline I could early, just to have an excuse to be up and around, just to listen, because I've heard nothing so far from the team.
I ate lunch in the empty set of cubicles that look out to the shop floor, pushing away the furloughed purchasers' junk they refused to take home. I watched my father toil away on the floor, sorting through the bins of KANBAN bolts and screws to make progress on his projects, none wiser...

column6: A collapse, a break-in, and a rescue drag Katiya and Cody violently back together.
column9:
A different feeling hits this time, and it's so much stronger than any other. I rush down the line of row houses on a street lit by lamplight, filled with the anticipation of catching a first glance at the damage to my home. But there isn't enough of a spectacle to draw neighbors.
With the element of surprise on my side, I turn into my next-door neighbor's front terrace and jump the short wrought-iron fence so I'm out of sight of my open door. There's no shattered glass...

column6: Katiya's first peaceful sleep leads straight into chaotic, sword-filled "fantasy" tourism on Earth.
column9:
Even in another world, I can't escape the same dream. The only difference is that sleep comes faster on a bed that's made of clouds, instead of one made from horsehair and feathers.
I'm not sure how we got here, but it was something about the way he still trembled although he insisted he was alright — still looking like he was on the verge of tears from the fear of what transpired. Maybe it's my empathy for that paralyzing, sticky feeling of fear that I know better tha...

column6: Katiya's first peaceful sleep leads straight into chaotic, sword-filled "fantasy" tourism on Earth.
column9:
My phone vibrates beneath the pillow and I wake around 9:30, expecting to be alone — but instead of hearing birdsong through the open window, I hear snippets of words and songs playing on the other side of the bed.
"Hey, you. You're finally awake," Katiya says. Her eyes don't leave the screen of the smartphone as she scrolls through memes and reels.
"And you're still here." I feel a wetness on my forehead that I touch with two fingers, and when she notices, she blushes. "Di...

column6: Katiya's first peaceful sleep leads straight into chaotic, sword-filled "fantasy" tourism on Earth.
column9:
"And I got it on an internet web site, on the computer," Rayna says, as her slitted pupils stare at me from across the room. "Contacts. Described by a doctor."
"And the ears? And the tail?" Kei asks, getting Reed to tie the pirate corset behind her. "How did you get those so perfect?"
I mouth the letters to her before Miguel makes it in my doorway.
"Eat...see. Eat-see," she says.
"Oh, Etsy?"
"Yeah, that," Rayna says, then remembers, "but you can't touch them, because they're fragile!"...

column6: Tournament glory and a stolen moment of closeness are shattered with sudden news from the north.
column9:
The first half of the morning goes on without much of a hitch. That was, until some toddler grabbed Rayna's tail before screaming KITTY! and launched her almost twice as high as a person should be able to jump. Then the child's mother told him "not to grab things he doesn't know where they connect to" — and since Rayna didn't get the connotation, I was lucky that I didn't have to explain it.
I spent most of my time explaining Dungeons & Dragons to Katiya, after sh...

column6: Tournament glory and a stolen moment of closeness are shattered with sudden news from the north.
column9:
"You said you promised," I say. "You said you'd let me win for him. So why are you fighting so hard?"
"Those other fighters were nothing," Rayna says, as the two of us circle in the center of the dirt arena. "I've got a taste for it again. I haven't fought like this since the Academy, and you're the only one that's put up a fight!"
"Then it's no wonder you're so rusty," I say, launching another jab at her as she leaps backward. It's hard not to use Essenc...

column6: Tournament glory and a stolen moment of closeness are shattered with sudden news from the north.
column9:
The pride of my fictional victory is enough to earn a restful night of sleep in Cody's bed, but it doesn't come to me quickly. We face in opposite directions with a sheet still separating us, and while I glance out the window to watch the metallic automobiles zip past beneath the miracle of electric light, I listen to Cody's uneven breathing.
And it's not even that he's snoring or gasping — but they're short and heavy and persistent, and for the longest time,...

column6: At work, a meeting becomes a reckoning. Someone steps forward, and the cost is real.
column9:
When I rise from four hours of sleep, I find that same feeling of dread I found in college when the world finally caught up with me, when I remembered it was a heavy day of finals. But this was a test I couldn't study for.
I usually leave no later than 6:30, but I awoke around 5:00, finding the knight still sleeping next to me. But it was like waking from a restless night with a severe cold, because once my conscious mind became aware of the great discomfort, there wasn't a chance I w...

column6: At work, a meeting becomes a reckoning. Someone steps forward, and the cost is real.
column9:
When I arrive in the west-facing conference room, flanked by a phalanx of employees I've never met before, I find the shutter shades drawn so tightly that the only glow in the room comes from their laptop screens. From the long chain of tables spanning most of the room, with three chairs on one side and seven on the other, I can tell the seating is assigned since there's only one spot left to fill.
Naveen sits in the left chair, and my father sits in the right, still refusing to turn ...

column6: At work, a meeting becomes a reckoning. Someone steps forward, and the cost is real.
column9:
The men of the Dunsmore family are the best at taking bullets. And as the only one left whose number hasn't been called, I carry enough survivor's guilt for the three of us.
I was prepared to be vanished today. The private sector dodges a lot of the slow, bureaucratic cycle of government, and I was sure they'd already drawn the documents for my termination, but they left themselves another option just in case. So after they got their pound of flesh through my father, I was no lon...

column6: Desperation pulls Katiya beyond the walls, where duty, grief, and old ghosts converge.
column9:
It's a new feeling that finds me when I'm rushing through the open streets, one I felt the day before when I heard Cody's voice cheering my name. It's an energy that races my circuits with the same signature of power but a different medium — like how human Essence can give rise to powers of both life and fire — and if Cody's faith in me lifted a sense of life, it's a fear for Bertram that blazes a fire.
The feeling carries me through the streets in a ru...

column6: Desperation pulls Katiya beyond the walls, where duty, grief, and old ghosts converge.
column9:
The clattering of hooves ceases when I break the line between cobblestone and dirt. I fight the blinding smoke for enough vision to lead Soot as my eyes water, breathing shallowly in the space behind Soot's neck that he drafts with air. While Soot toils with speed, my mind races over coming up with a plan: something, anything to turn Bertram around and get him back home safe. 
I race along the trail around the lake, the one I know from running every morning. For the longest time, I hear no...

column6: Desperation pulls Katiya beyond the walls, where duty, grief, and old ghosts converge.
column9:
The chill of death is no different than it was all those years ago. The cries of the victims are just as hushed as they were in the siege when the village is so sparsely spread between the pines, but there are still the diminishing sounds of combat.
I pass through a smoldered gate once carved by my father's hands. His handiwork lives on in all that's left of the intricate carvings: two burnt half-posts left from an arch that once had our village's name. 
But my hands don't t...

column6: Kindness and rediscovery of an old passion dare Cody to care again.
column9:
The drawing reads REED because he forgets to use his last name. It was checked by SAKURASHIMA, then approved by PRADESH, and now the chain of custody ends in my greasy hands, putting it all together.
The red toolbox won't be fooled by the hand-me-down fatigues that were just my size, because even if the woven tag reads DUNSMORE, and my likeness is spread across twelve Polaroid photos of my father and I — magnetized to the inner lid like a refrigerator door — I don't know w...

column6: Kindness and rediscovery of an old passion dare Cody to care again.
column9:
I tilt the glass until the liquid beats the foam. My phone buzzes with messages and notifications from friends, all sending the same default message. But there's a message from the group chat with my parents: one that I've still hesitated to open.
"They tried to call, but I couldn't bring myself to answer," I tell Kei and Reed. "I feel like an asshole. But, birthday or not, I'm just not ready to talk yet."
They sit across from me in the booth, and we look like we come from t...

column6: Kindness and rediscovery of an old passion dare Cody to care again.
column9: The warmth from their kindness lasts until I get off the highway: it's not from the single drink I had, because I'm fully sober. Maybe it's because I've been listening to music and audiobooks all day to make it through the grind, getting home so exhausted that I just pass out instead of letting all the life I haven't processed catch up with me. I haven't been clearing the rock from the hole I've dig myself into, and at bedrock, I'm afraid of going any fur...

column6: Shame, buried memories, and unexpected visitors push both worlds toward a new kind of war.
column9:
"She was trying to save him," Jullian says. "Bertram left and we did nothing — but it was Katiya that was braver than all of us!"
"Bravery is nothing without tact," Aldrin says, "have the three of you learned nothing? You disobeyed direct orders!"
The shame forces my glance to never leave the bodies. I stand at the back window, watching twenty-some Senior Guards walk the landscape southeast in a perfect line. Several analyze the remains of my best friend: his face still frozen between rel...

column6: Shame, buried memories, and unexpected visitors push both worlds toward a new kind of war.
column9:
The ride back is a whole lot slower. This time Soot carries two of us: my brother and I, as Jullian and Aryn ride behind on their own horses. The impalement is still there: medics cut the obsidian down with red-hot iron using the Essence blade I'm no longer privileged to, filed it down, and wrapped it. Looking over Erik's shoulder, the haze has almost cleared enough to see home.
I hug Erik's waist, wondering how many times left I have to spend with him. The adrenaline fades away ...

column6: Shame, buried memories, and unexpected visitors push both worlds toward a new kind of war.
column9:
My body shivers and strains from that tantrum in the cold. I sit on the toilet seat in the spare bathroom as a turbulent stream of water turns laminar when I draw back the faucet.
I rushed home to make the slides on the computer: down to two slides that pose the problem and the solution. I worked on the prototype and sped through it for three solid hours, making a model for my 3D printer to run as I wrote all the code in C++ for fast execution and idyllic control system latency for either the p...

column6: Shame, buried memories, and unexpected visitors push both worlds toward a new kind of war.
column9:
It's the refugee crisis that's kept the Royal Guard distracted. Ever since some mountain in Blackwater blew its top, a steady stream of human refugees flows through Gaffesend, headed south to the capital to start again.
I've met with my friends during the last couple days, no more than a civilian in this town that rejects me. Ryder insists that this event is what he's been waiting for, taking up an oar for every ferry ride from dawn to dusk to ask if anyone knows a Romin or ...

column6: This time, Katiya and Cody come together instead of shutting each other out.
column9:
In the long, dragging years after college, I thought that all I could ever want was to waste my life as efficiently as possible. 
But I feel something different now as I sit in the foyer of a home I can barely afford, watching the first snow of the year lightly fall beyond the glass of my front window, sitting in a folding chair as I consider everything that brought me to this exact moment.
While my mind deliberates over whether I was actually going to kill myself — or just being pathetic...

column6: This time, Katiya and Cody come together instead of shutting each other out.
column9:
"What am I doing wrong?" I repeat, and as all the past comes back to catch me, I feel my breaths shorten. 
The trauma from my past has made me so combustible. 
"All it ever feels like is I was made to burn," I say, feeling all those memories race my body with Essence, and if I don't slow my breathing, the life will leave my extremities. "I can't be calm — like Aryn, or you, and I just don't get it!"
The heat makes it hard for him to keep holding on, yet he doubles down, tho...

My own snore awakes me though Katiya is still fast asleep. I check my smartwatch: no texts show in the feed yet, but the digitally-analog hands read 3:40.
She leans against my shoulder, drooling on my shirt, her hair still disheveled with grass and leaves between the strands, and after I gently lower her to the thin cushions of the IKEA couch — wrapping her in a tasseled throw blanket called VINTERFINT — there's an unsettling energy that rises in my nerves.
I feel the urge to e...

"There was so much more to say," Rayna says, "but we didn't have the time. She said so little of who she was, but when we were captured together — sent to a certain death for betraying the Den — she used such tremendous power to save us that there's no doubt in my mind."
"Doubt about what?" I ask.
"That she's a Mask of the Ahkvasa. She didn't just stop time. She weaponized it," Rayna says. She sits on the couch in the same place Cody was, feeling the odd textures...

"I can't help you. No . . . but seriously, Katiya, I can't help you if you do this," I tell her. My face flushes from all the people that turn their heads.
"But I refuse," she says. "You either give all or give up, or else you leave no space to improve."
"You've left no space for more weights," I say, gesturing to the end of the barbell loaded with more plates than a gym rat might use on leg press. "This is enough for bench press: most girls your size do a five, or a ten on each ...

column6: Stories from another road change the map. A cross-world conversation reframes what "winning" could mean.
column9:
"This is a candy store," I say. "We can't get distracted by sweets! We're making our plan of attack."
"No, this is a shop that sells coffee," Cody says. "Starbucks. People come here to get work done."
I gesture to a lady eating a round, decorated sweet roll on a stick, as she types on her machine. "Why do your people have to reward themselves for doing work? You just do it," I say.
"Just wait until your world industrializes," Cody says. "You'll have more time than you know what t...
